title: Stanford's Christian McCaffrey finally getting the ball
text:
College Hotline blog STANFORD -- No topic was a greater source of frustration for Stanford fans during the step-back season of 2014 than the use (or lack thereof) of tailback Christian McCaffrey, perhaps the most versatile talent to play for the Cardinal since All-American Glyn Milburn. 
The frustrated throng, it should be noted, included Milburn himself. 
"There's no question he's the most dynamic back they've had," said Milburn, who holds the NFL record for all-purpose yards in a game. "He's not just a special weapon you bring off the shelf now and then." 
McCaffrey has moved front and center this season, combining with quarterback Kevin Hogan to invigorate an offense that often struggled to score 20 points in the years after Andrew Luck's departure. 
After a sputtering start that now looks like an aberration, the 15th-ranked Cardinal has topped the 40-point mark three games in a row entering its showdown Thursday night against No. 18 UCLA. 
In those games, McCaffrey gained a staggering 812 all-purpose yards. 
Most have come on the ground as he fills the No. 1 tailback role previously occupied by Toby Gerhart, Stepfan Taylor and Tyler Gaffney. But McCaffrey is also an adept receiver and dangerous punt and kickoff returner. 
"His all-purpose yards are off the charts," UCLA coach Jim Mora told reporters earlier this week. "He's just a really tremendous player." 
The combination of skills makes McCaffrey, whose father, Ed, was a Stanford receiver and three-time Super Bowl winner, one of the most versatile playmakers in school history. Advertisement 
In the modern era, the shortlist starts with Darrin Nelson in the early 1980s, skips a decade to Milburn, then jumps a quarter century to McCaffrey, who is second in the nation in all-purpose yards (229.8) behind San Jose State's Tyler Ervin. 
At his current pace, McCaffrey will challenge the Pac-12 single-season record in that category (2,890), which is held, coincidentally, by one of his childhood idols: Reggie Bush. 
"The best backs are the most complete backs," said McCaffrey, who switched to uniform No. 5 this season to match the number Bush wore at USC. "I tell myself that every day when I come to work." 
It took Stanford (4-1, 3-0) more time to fully integrate McCaffrey than many fans wanted. 
McCaffrey, whose mother, Lisa, played soccer at Stanford, was a heavily recruited prospect at Valor Christian High School in the Denver suburbs. He committed to Stanford in the final weeks of his junior year, then rewrote the Colorado high school record book as a senior. 
It took only a few days of his first training camp for McCaffrey, with his speed and power, to establish himself as a threat to score from anywhere on the field. 
"Ed came to one of the last scrimmages of training camp," coach David Shaw recalled. "I said, 'If (Christian) redshirts, there might be a revolt.' " 
McCaffrey averaged 9.3 yards per touch as a running back and receiver but had only 4.5 opportunities per game despite the Cardinal's desperate need for production. According to Shaw and offensive coordinator Mike Bloomgren, McCaffrey wasn't well-versed enough in the massive Cardinal playbook -- and particularly in the pass protection schemes -- to warrant full-time duty. 
Why not change the playbook to get McCaffrey on the field more often? 
"That doesn't fit who we are," Bloomgren explained. "I like to think of it as sophisticated simplicity. But if it's too simple, it doesn't take advantage of our greatest strength, which is how smart our kids are." 
McCaffrey spent the offseason learning the playbook to the point that everything is second nature. He also prepared his body for a heavy workload, adding approximately 10 pounds of muscle -- his playing weight is now 205 -- without losing speed. 
Instead of discussing ways to get him on the field more often, the coaches now monitor McCaffrey's touches to guard against overuse. 
Instead of playing him out wide, in the slot and in the backfield, he is now locked into the tailback spot. 
"From day one, I was thinking, 'Wow, who's that kid?' " said Milburn, whose NFL single-game record of 404 all-purpose yards for Denver has stood for 20 years. 
"He's making a name on his own. He's no longer Ed's son. He's a highlight reel." For more on college sports, see Jon Wilner's College Hotline at blogs.mercurynews.com/collegesports . Contact him at jwilner@mercurynews.com or 408-920-5716.
